turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Bathers at Asnières.
turn.1: What is meant by perceptual colours?
turn.2: In this way, colour perception was explained as a complex, interpretive process, rather than a static and simple record of visual data.
turn.3: Did Seurat experiment with perceptual colours?
turn.4: Seurat’s response to the theories in these writings is widely evident in the Bathers, most obviously in such areas as those of the torso and legs of the man seated centre-left on the persimmon-orange cushion, and of the central figure as his back contrasts with light blue water and his arm contrasts with water of a darker hue.
turn.5: What was Seurat's life like in 1882?
turn.6: In 1882 Seurat rented a small studio in the rue Chabrol close to his family’s home.
turn.7: What did he paint in the studio?
turn.8: " Bathers at Asnières" was painted in this studio, on a canvas identical in size to that part of "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte" that excludes the painted border.
turn.9: Did he have any other paintings?
turn.10: Following the rejection of the "Bathers" by the jury of the Salon of 1884, Seurat joined forces with some like-minded artists to become a founder members of the "Groupe des Artistes Indépendants".
turn.12: This institution held its first exhibition—the "Salon de Artistes Indépendants"—between May 15th and July 1st, 1884 at a temporary building in the place du Carrousel, adjacent to the Louvre.
